text:
Hi Tom! I like to start by evaluating my buyer personas and answering the questions they may have along their journey. Think of your content like a roadmap that guides the buyer down their journey to solve their problem.

Your top of funnel content is more high-level and making them aware that there is a problem/pinpointing their particular problems (according to their buyer persona). Your middle content is giving them info on different ways to solve their problem. Bottom of funnel is showing the buyer how your company solves their problem.

Try Storybrand's content roadmap workshop and here's a really helpful Hubspot Academy course: <https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/content-strategy>

attachments.text: In this free course, you’ll learn how to take a more strategic approach to the content your business creates, and ultimately drive greater results.
attachments.title: Courses & Lessons | HubSpot Academy

elements.text:
Hi Tom! I like to start by evaluating my buyer personas and answering the questions they may have along their journey. Think of your content like a roadmap that guides the buyer down their journey to solve their problem.

Your top of funnel content is more high-level and making them aware that there is a problem/pinpointing their particular problems (according to their buyer persona). Your middle content is giving them info on different ways to solve their problem. Bottom of funnel is showing the buyer how your company solves their problem.

Try Storybrand's content roadmap workshop and here's a really helpful Hubspot Academy course:

text:
Start with your product(s). List out the functionality and use cases. Publish content about the problems and challenges related to those. 

Some of it will explicitly feature your product(s), some of it will make light mention, and some will only hit at the functionality. 

The latter two cater to people who are unaware of their problems or only just begun to understand their problems. Content that helps them become aware or understand their problems earns trust. It also makes them more aware of solutions—solutions like your product(s) were made to tackle. 

The former is tailored for the folks who understand their problems and consider your product(s) to be viable. This is when content needs to persuade them that it's the most viable.

The latter two cater to people who are unaware of their problems or only just begun to understand their problems. Content that helps them become aware or understand their problems earns trust. It also makes them more aware of solutions—solutions like your product(s) were made to tackle.
The former is tailored for the folks who understand their problems and consider your product(s) to be viable. This is when content needs to persuade them that it's the most viable.
